Blog.post: Why is it that I never see myself on Blogger's 10 most recently published list? Chinese new years eve is really cool this year. There's not a car on the streets, giving you a very unusual but much welcomed calmness. Then there's the variety of firecrackers that's been going off people's roofs and driveways all through the day and into the night. Calmness + firecrackers...ha ha. Inconsistent but not contradictory. On a sad note, I'm pretty horrified to find out that according to Chinese tradition, you get the red envelope on new years until you are married. So after a certain age, when your relatives give you red envelopes, they are actually handing out reminders that you are an overgrown child and an old maid. Fairly cruel and painful. I read Ahoyhoyhoy's blog today and I must say, I totally agree: what are sinuses good for? They only make my blasted nose run every morning and cause bothersome bogie to accompany my nasal cavity through the day. Then there's the boy question: what if you just end up with a repressed Christian man hiding behind the jargon? Why not just forget the fundraiser and go with the drug addict? : ) Good thing I'm not dating, right?

Happy Chinese New Years! I went to Taipei with my sister today. After walking through all those department stores, shops, and vendors, we still end up coming home with stuff from Net (none of us ever wondered what that name meant, huh?). What a boring pair we are : ) Why is it that I feel like I'm forever a teenager when I'm with my mother? Perhaps that's just what mothers do -- to remind you that even if none others do, they can and will still be able to exasperate you. I watched Wallace and Gromit today and realized that I really miss cheese. I wish I had a dog that I could go to the moon with to bring some back.

I saw a movie on tv the other day and decided to dub Madeline Stowe "the affair woman", just as Juliette Binoche is "the naked lady". Might not be totally accurate, but hey...might relieve some of the shock if the former starts sleeping with a priest or if the latter suddenly stripped nude and stayed that way (for those with whom I watched Damage in that shady "MTV" place across from Sunrise in 8th grade: it was very damaging indeed). I'm re-reading some of the Chronicles of Narnia books and realized that they are indeed a bit too allegorical. Might be all right if the story-telling was good; but sadly, it just doesn't compare with the genius of Harry Potter . I've decided to move onto C.S. Lewis' adult stuff. We'll see how that is.

I miss San Diego! I miss my old roommates, the nice Nobel Court and Costa Verde apartments, and even the gyms that I go to only once a quarter. I miss VH1, Bravo, ABC, NBC, HBO, and the TV Guide Channel. I even miss channels that my friends like to watch - MTV, Animal Planet, Lifetime, TLC - you know who you are. Have you ever been haunted by the ghost of a bridge you burnt (or caught fire by itself, in some cases), and wondered why it even bothers you? I'm reminded today of the corollary to Luke 7:47 - he who has been forgiven much loves much. I love little because I forget how much I've been forgiven; and if I love much, what is there that I can't forgive?

And I don't want anymore emails from Raunchy Rachel either. When I try to download Michelle Branch's "Sweet Misery", Kazaa's adult filter notice comes up. That's just sick. Bye-bye Lisa! There's no knowing now just how many people has it because it has a 2-week incubation period. My dad says, "Check the news in two weeks to make sure Taiwan is still around." aiyo! I Went Downtown Yesterday and saw a young beggar in front of Kingstone. He was a boy of less than 15 years - "just like my brother", I thought. Except that he was mentally and physically handicapped and spent his days sitting half-splayed on the ground. He wore no shoes, as if they were too good for the cold dirty walkway on which he sat. Some people did spare their change for him, offering the only perceivable consolation. It must seem like comfort in a broken, blackened plastic bowl. It's a comfort that he can't even pick up and touch, for those thin arms hung somewhat uselessly against his sides. When the bustling of the city finally dies down at night, a certain man or woman must come to take him home. Will it be any warmer than his daytime spot? They might take out a cold lunch pack and feed him. Maybe he understands, and maybe he doesn't. Would he care about the stickiness on his legs or what comes with his rice tonight? Would he wish for his parents' comfort or that they would simply spank him less harshly? It looked so strange that everyone should walk about him dressed in the latest fashion and carrying expensive cell phones. Should I get the white blouse with pink flowers or the azure one with blue flowers? It didn't matter.

Some new minnie-thoughts: Ode to a Pachyderm I didn't know that the world's oldest elephant in captivity was right here in Taiwan (!), until it passed away last week. The news made headlines, and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeo awarded it a posthumous honorary citizen's certificate. It's sweet that the people loved and took care of it so well. It is said that elephants have impeccable memory and that they somehow have an innate knowledge of their ancestors' burial grounds, which they go in search of when they are dying. I wonder if Lin Wang the elephant was thinking of his home in Burma and that secret place where his family awaits when he died in his pen. Now when you apply that to pizza, that would mean corn or thousand island dressing. Luckily, it's got nothing of the sort and is very good. I do think that some Japanese went to California and sent news back about In-N-Out, because they figured out how to make the buns crispy around the sides. Mmm. He's changing me My precious Jesus I'm not the person that I used to be Sometimes it's slow going But there's a knowing That someday, perfect I will be. from Friday, June 16 - Genesis 13. When the time came for Abram and Lot to separate, Abram in his generosity and humility offered Lot the choice between two lands. Lot looked up, and seeing that the plain of the Jordan was lush and pleasing, chose it for himself. I've always thought that it meant Lot was a selfish bastard (or nephew), end of the story. Naturally, that wasn't the point. Lot did what any of us should do - make informed, logical, and practical judgments. If the lives of my family, flocks, and herds were dependent on my choosing one land over another, I should hope that I choose the better-looking one. God isn't saying, "Make sure you choose the worst of the lands. It must be dry and rocky, so you can't water your flocks or grow any crops.". The problem wasn't in Lot's decision, but the criteria on which he based it. He chose what was pleasing to his eyes and pitched his tents near Sodom, even though the men there were wicked and sinful. God is telling us, as he told Abram, to "lift up your eyes from where you are." The fertile land we look for is not on earth but in heaven, and faith is to be like Abram and acknowledge the Lord in all that he does. I could really use this lesson because I base so many of my choices, conscious or unconscious, on my "eyes". I'm so easily lured away by what looks attractive or promising that I'm completely blinded from God's criteria. The songs we teach kids at sunday school can be very applicable to ourselves: "Trust and obey, there is no other way. To be happy in Jesus is to trust and obey!" So why is the giraffe green? I guess it's time to tell the story behind the namesake for this blog, for whoever wants to know in the future. Last summer I went to visit my friend at UCLA. We were at a Longs Drug and I spotted this stuffed animal smiling from a shelf. "Oh Jenny, look look, it's a green giraffe!" I shouted excitedly "Yeah, it's really cute. Are you going to get it?" I did, and clutched it happily as we proceeded to the checkout. By the time we reached the counter, Jenny was suddenly able to put into words what had been troubling her for a few long minutes. "Wait Minnie, that's not a giraffe." "What?" I was incredulous. "It's a dinosaur" "What?!" I suddenly recognized it for what it was but stubbornly denied it. "Minnie, I saw the real giraffe over there ..." [pointing to an aisle we just passed] "Well, this one's green so it's different!" That same night, Sandra and Lisa drove down from Berkeley and confirmed that it was not a giraffe. I'll never admit that to you, though. We had a good time laughing at his four closetfuls of fancy suits and color-coded shirt racks (I guess it's only funny if you knew that they were strictly reserved for Sunday wear). I also marvelled at his stack of bibles. Me: Wow, he really studies it Jess: So, do you want to marry him? Me: Um ... out of love for you, Jess. Here are the minimal requirements to be considered for Mrs. J. Tang -- trendy, traditional, submissive, good cook, and a popular church member. So now I know why he's single, but why am I? ;) I was commenting to Jessica about how someday, I want to get it on the record that I have ADD, SAD, and Narcolepsy. Jess: No problem. When I get my license to practice, I'll give you whatever diagnoses you want. Me: Wow Jess, I don't now how to repay you! I suppose I could hook you up with prescription drugs. Jess: Okay! Nerd at heart Dick has been savoring the thought of being on top of the (academic) world and graduating with a handful of attractive job offers to "settle" for. Me: No wait, you still have to get the Nobel Prize and Dick's Law of ... I forgot, what was it? Dick: Co's Law Me: Co's Law? Sounds like a salad. Dick: He he he. That's exactly my point. Me: Ha ha ha. [Pause] We're such nerds.

"80% of life is just showing up". Our commencement speaker quoted Woody Allen in his speech on Sunday. Being an easily distracted person, I only collected bits and pieces of the speech. The parts I caught were good, though not entirely coherent to me as I'm trying to recount the main points. Most people were just fiddling about and looking up to cheer to phrases such as "... graduated in 5 years", "... Revelle is the first and best college at UCSD", "... finishing the Humanities sequence", or "... Provost Bond will be retiring ...". It struck me how important it was being able to "show up". Five years ago, I did not envision graduation as it is today. I wanted Phi Beta Kappa, acceptance to medical school, and a steady boyfriend to take along. It's good to be reminded that "Many are the plans in a man's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails (Pr 19:21)." God's purpose was to reveal my sinfulness, my pathetic strongholds, my self-defeating attitudes, and ultimately, his immeasurable grace. "But he said to me, "My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness." Therefore I will boast all the more gladly about my weaknesses, so that Christ's power may rest on me (2 Co 12:9)." Amen! So the speaker's point was to tell us to always question why we showed up and to remember to get lucky in life. For him, luck = preparation + opportunity. I guess it meant that everything we work hard at is meaningful, because opportunity is nothing if without the preparation. It was encouraging, commending, and everything you need to hear at a commencement, I suppose :) . So we moved our tassels to the left, released the doves, and this is the end. I realized that there are so many people I had still to meet (like the CAPE guy that looks like Jet Li) and so many people I wish I met earlier (like my 5th year roommates or that Joe who graduated my freshman year) and the English major I never switched to. But before I cry for my loss, I have to first rejoice in my gains. I would not have had a taste of any of the many blessings throughout these years if it wasn't for God's grace. I would not have been able to understand that they were blessings at all. I would not have "shown up".

After spending some time with a friend yesterday, I felt a mixture of emotions. For no apparent reason, I started thinking about The Bluest Eye . Why would a woman love someone else's children more than her own? Why would a black woman love someone else's white children more than her own? She despises her own kind. She feels more honor in being a surrogate for another family than in her own God-given motherhood. A person can feel rightly discriminated against because she has learned to despise who she is. Why do women allow themselves to be oppressed? I know of a girl who grew up in a family of deluded men. Their attitudes are so outlandishly chauvinistic that it's almost comical. What's not amusing is that the women condone it. They accept the stifling ignorance of a tradition. They consent to the oppressiveness of a backward culture. They consciously protect the male ego and offer themselves up as magnifying glasses for men. They unconsciously depreciate themselves, scorning their daughters and revering their sons. What's the sociological factor behind this psychology; or what is the psychological factor behind this sociology? Maybe it's just the age-old curse, "Your desire will be for your husband, and he will rule over you." So what do we do about that? I recall reading Elisabeth Elliot for a women's bible study last summer, and it just frustrated me more. Some of my discipler's parting words to me were, "When you acknowledge the price that God paid for you in sacrificing his only son, you will appreciate your infinite value and royal status as a daughter of the King." I miss sharing in her wisdom. I guess it's time to make an appointment with the King. It's always - seek him first, ask later. Right? (can't really answer, can you?) So I think this ranks as one of those ramblings that make absolutely no sense. Oh well, it's my nonsensical blog, so there.

I Left My Heart in San Francisco? It's been exactly a week since I arrived on the east coast. My state of mind controls so much of how I feel about things. For instance, weather. On a happy day, rain is music/ soothing/ drops of friendly coolness/ a pleasant contrast to my sunny disposition. On an unhappy day, rain is pathetic fallacy/ dampening/ a mean threat to finish off my dying spirit. On a happy day, the sun is good company/ heartwarming/ the light the shines on my green green meadow. On an unhappy day, the sun is a mockery/ irritating/ an unbearable brightness violating the shade of my ill humor. Today, it's the sunset. I'm very fond of it. I think it's beautiful, romantic, and oftentimes the best part of the day. That is, if the sun sets over the ocean . I was leaning over the pier of South Street Seaport viewing the Brooklyn Bridge, thinking of how pretty it is and yet how I despise the town across the water to which it leads. I felt like the dusk kind of just crept in on me as the view over the water dimmed. No comfort from a sinking ball of light with a reddish glow nor purple streaks across the sky nor white clouds with a brightness against the darkening blue as though instead of carrying vapor, it's holding in every last ounce of light from the waning sun. Okay, I have to stop this melodrama. So I guess I'm still getting over the shock of my first few days here -- trekking down, up, and across Brooklyn under a merciless late summer sun; waiting as though to be cooked through and charred in the dirty subway stations; stepping out into Chinatown and feeling a wave of confused horror because I think I'm in Taiwan - complete with the taxicabs, grime, and humidity. Also, I seem to be getting in everybody's way. I've been pushed from behind by impatient pedestrians with large carrier shopping bags or briefcases, going about their oh-so-important business. I've tripped on the stairs, tripped on a boy with an icecream cone in his hand, tripped across the street as a UPS truck came speeding up the street at me... Other than that, New York City is quite beautiful. I've been missing my friends so much and been thinking about how undeserving I am sometimes. I rarely make myself available to help others; but when I'm in need, I call up everyone I know and everybody I know that my friends know without hesitation. I'm so grateful for the people who have given me thought, advice, encouragement, and prayer this past week. You know who you are (or aren't! just kidding). I'm feeling much more relieved and at peace now. I know I'll be stressing through the rest of the year, but I'll just have to take it as it comes. I would also like to add that my apartment search through the city has led me to one obvious and oh-so-simple answer: where there is a Starbucks, there a liveable place be. The only Starbucks in Brooklyn are in Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and Brooklyn Heights ... see that? Wow. I have just discovered the Starbucks Coffee Test for Safe Neighborhoods. I could say more, but the train of thought has stopped. :) That's contradictory. Oh, whatever.

Some things people say really irritate me. Of course we all know that oftentimes it's not what they say but how they say it that affects how you receive the message. This definitely applies to writing. I have opinions too (hence this spiel), but I get worked up when people approach something in such a way that who they are overpowers what they have to say. When the writer's unwelcomed personality peeps into every other sentence, it really detracts value and credibility from the piece. I find this in books, articles, web logs, what-have-you. God created three sexes: Male, Female, and You. Now I've come across a bit of talk about metrosexuality, and it makes me wonder if I have any take on the subject. Since the definition of the metrosexual male allows for a wide range of qulifications, it doesn't really specify the particular type and degree of gayness that men in this category need possess. While there may be a stereotypical metrosexual, there's room for a lot of diversity. So how much is too much, and how gay is too gay? For one, I think it's a good thing for guys to care about their appearance. I've seen guys sneak on Chapstick as though it's unnatural and impolite. Don't think I don't understand that men and women are genetically different, and that applies to epidermal tissue. But, everyone's skin needs taking care of and everyone's lips chap. Why do men have to pretend theirs don't? I don't care if some guy has the entire Shiseido Pureness line (if he really needs it). I'm all for fairness. Now some girls might think, "but only women should pamper themselves and use expensive personal care products." Give me the logic for that, and I might change my mind. I'm not supporting the pampering of skin for either sex, mind you. I do think they should have the same rights to it. A typical store at the mall will sell more women's apparel than men's. Women's clothes also have more variety, detail, and in general look "nicer". A garment for men may have the same price and plainer look, but it definitely has more quality and practicality than the women's version. Why do men's jackets have interior pockets and women's don't? Why are men's shirts made of good substantial material while women's shirts are only available in sheer handwash-only fabric? Everyone knows I'm a fan of sheer cotton/mesh/whatever; but when I want a normal t-shirt, I expect to find one. It shouldn't be assumed that women only wear clothes for show and that if they get cold, they can go borrow a guy's sweater. There's more to life than being really really really ridiculously good looking. A guy should care about his appearance, but he should not be any more vain than a girl should. I'm all for fairness. Why should women be excused for vanity while an analogous attitude in men is disparaged as narcissism? I appreciate guys with good taste. On Saturday, I went shoe shopping with Dick. I can see my own mother as one who attempts to find a middle ground, but the result looks pretty messy to me. ___________________________ My dad asked me a few times how one would translate the Chinese phrases "boo[\]-how[v]-yee[\]-shr[v]" (BHYS) and "suh[v]-boo[\]-duh[/]" (SBD). I believe there just might not be an English equivalent, because these phrases express very cultural-specific Chinese ideas. BHYS an expression of politeness 1. Used when asking for pardon, as in excuse me 2. When you are embarrassed or shy about doing something 3. When you do something not out of desire but from a feeling of obligation. For example, I dont want to go to the party but I feel BHYS to not go. Another example - Person A says, Dont walk me home, Ill be BHYS. Person B replies, No no, let me walk you home. Otherwise, I will be BHYS. --> Essentially, either of these usages contains a hard on the face factor. I dont think Americans readily understand the concept of saving face, because it comes from this kind of pride veiled by false modesty. So I guess I would define BHYS as: Origin, Chinese. An expression of politeness often characterized by false modesty. SBD lit. difficult to expend or let go 1. Used when you cant throw away something sentimental 2. Also used when you cant bear to let someone you care about endure hardship (often found in cheesy writing) or to watch them go away (ex. when a father gives his daughter away in marriage).

Sometimes when I'm talking with someone and both of us are pouring out our struggles, life feels like a mess. I feel, "oh my gosh, my life is going nowhere as of right this moment. It is a complete mess!" But then all it takes is for one of us to remember one thing which God has blessed, and we know that He is faithful and life is good. Our God is in control. I spent 72 hours this past weekend at the Sheraton in Framingham, Massachussetts. It was the most intense indoor activity I've ever done - a three day church conference! Leaving aside a bundle of emotions and questions I have yet to sort out, I must say I was really blessed by all the testimonies that were given. The founding pastor's daughter, Pauline, told her story of being ... well, the pastor's daughter. Growing up, she was always what people expected of her. Outwardly, she behaved as the model PK - quiet, obedient, long-suffering. But inwardly, she was angry, jealous, and rebellious. Her mother was never at home, but rather travelling and working with college students. Her mother was never there to talk to her, take her shopping, tuck her in at night, etc. She would see her mother come home at all hours of the night, tired and worn out, only to answer phone calls and rush out again after a few hours of rest. She became jealous of the people her mother spent so much time teaching and counseling, and wondered if what her parents were doing was really all necessary. She would purposely disobey her parents and say things that she knew would hurt. She was so lonely by herself, with only her grandmother to care for her. During the past summer, she was finally able to spend one whole month with her mother while they were on the mission field in Tashkent. There, she saw the fruits of her mother's labor and the lives that were changed. She looks at the church now and realizes that what she didn't get from her immediate family she received ten times over from the church family. The people she saw her mom teach around the kitchen table as a child are the pastors and leaders of today, and they cared for her as their own. What was so beautiful about this is that the very thing that makes her testimony is what made the church possible. It is because of her mother's sacrifice, which she didn't understand and struggled against, that there is such a body of believers. In the beginning, I was just curious about what this pretty little harvard student pastor's daughter who sings like an angel has to "confess". Surely, she's a goodie-goodie, blessed by God and everyone else around her. But I was amazed at how simple yet powerful it is, that God is not interested in what you do but your heart. He's all about changing your heart, and only he knows our hearts and has the power to change it. Moreover, it's chilling to see that the mother's sacrifice that makes this testimony tug at your heartstrings is the very reason why there is such a joyful family of believers. Sacrifice is something I confess I really don't understand, but this story made me realize how it could be a more than a good thing. This girl's mother, Rebekah JDSN (Korean for "minister") later read to us a thanksgiving letter she received from a Berkeley sister. It talked about how she's learned a lot about life while working as a nursing student. One thing she realized was that, she's been unfairly blessed. Becky jdsn pointed out that it was a very good use of the word. We mostly know how to use the word "unfair" with a childish attitude. But this sister understood a better use for the word. We were challenged to ask ourselves, do we have such a gratitude toward God that our only complaint is, "Why Should He Love Me So?" If we have anything to complain to God about, it should be "why have you so unfairly blessed me while the rest of the world is lost?" I am truly humbled!

But, I shall attempt to recount a little. The text was 2 Samuel 23:13-17, "The Warriors". To be a Christian warrior involves humility and knowing full well who you are before the Lord. David behaved as he did (pouring out the water that his warriors had broken through enemy lines and bravely fetched) because he knew that there was nothing he nor they should take credit for; everything was God's grace. I thought at first it was just a loyalty-garnering strategy that General Liu would've done in The Romance of the Three Kingdoms (is anyone fobby enough to know what I'm saying - in reference to the rescuing of Ah-Doh?), but this made sense too :). David wanted not water, but his reassurance back. Reassurance that he was king and that God was on his side. He poured the water out as a drink offering. To be a Christian warrior also means being like the mighty men in their love for David. David had said of the water only in sighing, but his warriors braved all odds to bring it back. Sure, they proved their strength and probably upped the morale significantly, but their being attuned to David's desires and quickness to please shows their love for him. Likewise, we are warriors when we do this for the Lord. So now that I've butchered the well-structured sermon and left out a million key points, I must admit this system of mental note-taking is not very effective. Anyway. Shall I begin a series on tales of high school nothings? My stalking activities led me to unearth certain memories from the tenth grade, which is to me "the limbo year" because it lingered somewhere between the rebellious mayhem of ninth grade and the golden age of eleventh. Demographically, tenth grade was somewhere between the mass defection of fellow classmates to TAS and the last-minute arrivals of William and Tina. Academically, it was somewhere between "screw school" and "I better study for the SAT if I want to get out of here." It was during this time that a rather interesting angst-filled former goth-turned-bubblegum punk girl named Rui Cheng joined the 10B class. While Lisa and Sandra were busy with student council and Jenny was busy with then boyfriend, I amused myself in Rui's company during her long cigarette breaks on the fifth floor stairwell. Schooldays were spent listening to her stories about performing arts school, growing up in New York, picking on "that loser Macaulay Culkin", having a white (and apparently bonehead) boyfriend who thought Chinese people had gray eyes, ballet dancing in Shanghai, the safe and economical way of body piercing with large safety pins, and how she really really wanted to kill herself. A few years later, she would've been the poster girl for Hot Topic; but in my opinion, she was the forerunner of all plastic lunchbox carrying Marilyn Manson-esque girls. I helped her cut out Hello Kitty pictures from popsicle boxes while she expounded on the reasons she hated her parents so much. After a rather dazed and confused semester, Miss Rui left. She came to me during afternoon cleanup one day and told me that her parents decided to let her go back to New York. She asked me if I would miss her. I said I wouldn't miss her, but I'd think about her. I kept true to my word. April 26, 2004. Friendster Message: Rui wrote: holy shit!!! I remember you. It's funny, I just saw Emily wang yesterday.
